author: Maarten Mittner
title: JSE gains despite weaker Asian, European markets | Markets
text:
Picture: JSE THE JSE shrugged off weaker global markets to close firmer on Tuesday in choppy trade, with gold stocks making the biggest gains, while banks and financials staged a relief rally and resources came under pressure.
Positive data in the US and UK encouraged risk-off trade for most of the day, causing the JSE to lose ground, but the all share recovered late in the afternoon as the Dow posted modest gains.
In the US third-quarter growth trackers indicated relatively strong gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 2.7% after July housing starts grew a monthly 0.2% in July, above market consensus.
In the UK, July CPI data surprised to the upside, setting the scene for potentially earlier than expected interest rate hikes in the UK.
Barclays Research said Chinese stocks were down about 6% following concerns that the Chinese authorities may be less supportive of share prices. Risky assets also fell while bonds gained in Thailand after the bomb blast in Bangkok, Barclays said.
The Shanghai Composite ended the session 6.15% lower and the Hang Seng lost 1.43%. The Dow Jones was flat at the JSE’s close (0.02%) and the FTSE 100 was 0.33% lower. The Paris CAC 40 was 0.15% lower and the German Dax had also lost 0.15%.
At 5pm the all share was up by 0.45% to 50,977 points and the blue-chip top 40 gained 0.4%. The gold index firmed 3.16%. Industrials rose 0.58%. Financials were also up by 0.58% and banks gained 0.49%. Property rose 0.42%. Resources dropped 0.48% and platinums shed 0.46%.
Glacier International MD Andrew Brotchie said the local market, however, remained under some pressure.
"It is difficult to see some good news."
On the whole, however, the market was not looking as bad as the rand, with the weaker currency supporting rand hedge stocks. The top 10 JSE stocks on market value earned 70% of their earnings offshore, he said.
But emerging markets could expect continued headwinds.
"Further capital outflows could materialise if the US hikes rates," Mr Brotchie said.
China’s growth was also slowing down, and this would continue to exert pressure on the global market scene, he said.
Among individual shares on the JSE, Anglo American was 1.26% lower at R150.20, while ArcelorMittal slumped 7.64% to R12.93.
Among the rand hedges SABMiller added 0.76% to R667.95 and British American Tobacco firmed 0.4% to R742.43.
Among gold stocks Harmony lost 1.87% to R12.60, but Sibanye closed 2.26% higher at R14.04.
Platinum producer Lonmin continued its losing streak, closing 4.49% down at R6.80.
FirstRand added 1.04% to R53.31 but Barclays Africa lost 1.03% to R178.48.
Retail giant Shoprite was 1.39% higher at R160.25 after reporting strong annual results on the day. Massmart Holdings rose 2.29% to R127.86 and Woolies added 1.85% to R102.
After losing nearly 10% in early trade, construction group Aveng recouped some of its losses in later trade, closing 2.73% lower at R4.98. It reported an annual loss on the day.
Among property stocks Resilient rose 1.62% to R113 and Growthpoint added 0.69% to R27.54.
Telkom rebounded 3.7% to R62.16.
Industrial conglomerate Remgro ended the day 2.88% firmer at R259.99.
